Posts.Content: On Jul 02, 2013 5:04 AM singinglady wrote: thank you chris for a very informed and outside mainstream recommendations;  i, myself, with somatostatinoma, cannot have prrt because my tumors do not light up on an octreoscan, probably because my own somatostatin blocks the scan and the folks in germany want that for starters; not sure i would have done it anyway, but i wanted to point out that i follow mainstream lab research and have been watching the studies involved in alternative fasting, now being done with chemo to ammeliorate the toxic effects, but the earlier studies with mice and then rats involved various fasting rhythms and actual cures of some of the cancers; now a fellow out at ucla named valter longo is working with these results and patients on chemo; the implications of his results, from which i infer that the cancer, cells as a result of fasting, commit suicide (i'm oversimplifying here) and the chemo is not effected at all but the side effects are clearly ameliorated,  and the thc data showing cures, recently replicated by a highly thought of Harvard scientist.   Be well. my experience w my own mastect yrs ago is that it takes time for the remaining skin to stretch into a comfortable shield and since this is the largest organ on (of) the human body, trauma to it is significant, but in my case, altho i had only a stage 0, in situ, i knew that the only way to be certain that there were no other microscopic ca's was to remove & dissect the breast; and, altho i loved the organ that fed my son, he was now grown........i ultimately had a saline implant put in after making both breasts a size c, down from d, to make the stretching prior to insert of the implant easier.  my superb reconstruction surgeon -- a plastic surgeon -- who takes all insurance, said that saline lasts not as long as......sorry blocked the other one since the leakage was not something i was willing to put into my body..........however, i am happy to report that that very implant has lasted over 25 years and lol this despite my occasionally sticking it with a pin that i was trying to pin to a lapel -------and no flat tire lol skin stretches, as we all, alas, know all too well as we watch the aging process     or after our 'baby carriage' has been emptied    lol        good luck with it       life is good
Posts.Title: EXTREME TIGHTNESS, Pressure against chest wall - Post Mastectomy

Posts.Content: thank you chris for a very informed and outside mainstream recommendations;  i, myself, with somatostatinoma, cannot have prrt because my tumors do not light up on an octreoscan, probably because my own somatostatin blocks the scan and the folks in germany want that for starters; not sure i would have done it anyway, but i wanted to point out that i follow mainstream lab research and have been watching the studies involved in alternative fasting, now being done with chemo to ammeliorate the toxic effects, but the earlier studies with mice and then rats involved various fasting rhythms and actual cures of some of the cancers; now a fellow out at ucla named valter longo is working with these results and patients on chemo; the implications of his results, from which i infer that the cancer, cells as a result of fasting, commit suicide (i'm oversimplifying here) and the chemo is not effected at all but the side effects are clearly ameliorated,  and the thc data showing cures, recently replicated by a highly thought of Harvard scientist.   Be well.

Posts.Content: On Jul 02, 2013 2:05 PM Chris12 wrote: When you say fasting do you mean drinking only liquids and no solid foods, maybe a veg juice only fast, or do you mean cutting back only on sugar? Fasting sounds dangerous to me, especially when on chemo, unless maybe it's more of a veg/fruit juice only fast. forgive me, but i still have not figured out which post i'm responding to, but since i spoke of fasting, it is a water fast; i have coffee (i know, i know and i once spent 10 yrs w no caffeine and none of the 15 or so foods i tested sensitive to via the alyssa and another test -- i regularly flew clients blood to a lab in california for 2 tests more sensitive to our responses than mainstream allergy tests) that i tested positive to, but i have not yet gone back to that     because as i'm sure you know, chris, whatever we are 'allergic' to, we are addicted to and i have been so busy trying to keep our wonderful doctors from killing me.  it's an interesting razor's edge that some of us dance on lol       if you look at the original lab animal tests on fasting     no chemo involved      and then the later work such as valter longo, whom i'm sure i've mentioned........ok, now i'm simply blahblah ing be well
